item.title: Emmanuel Macron has spoken to Vladimir Putin 16 times since December. This dialogue has its critics, but makes it hard for his rivals to compete https://t.co/DBCjKezJz2

“I worry that if Putin conquers Ukraine, he will turn to Lithuania next, so I’m here fighting for my own country as much as I am for Ukraine.” Why foreigners are flocking to a war zone https://t.co/HG4hm6T1Ch
This week’s cartoon from KAL: https://t.co/hHYCvUaALC https://t.co/zV1vcWdTzK
Many pets remain in Ukraine. Kyiv’s metro stations—now bomb shelters—are full of pets snuggling quietly with their owners https://t.co/hgKdHeWoWd
Olaf Scholz has pulled the plug on Nord Stream 2 and aims to reduce Germany’s reliance on Russian energy. Few expected the typically cautious chancellor to react so decisively https://t.co/o5SdHYQC1y
What sets Mrs Thomas apart is not only her activism but also the fact that she is married to a Supreme Court justice, Clarence Thomas https://t.co/46VtsJHeQm
Hong Kong’s case-fatality rate of 2% is more than ten times higher than those of New Zealand, Singapore and South Korea https://t.co/YIseqlwXcH
The trains are fast becoming the arteries of Ukraine’s wartime being, moving refugees and exports west, and critical humanitarian supplies back to the centre https://t.co/7jOIYc8MQs

Having defended democracy, Western countries need to reinforce it. Joined-up action on trade and defence would send a warning to China about what would happen were it to invade Taiwan https://t.co/kPzSyKTaAq

“Vladimir Putin does not need to be led by hand out of this. He went into this war and he will find his way out, but only if he smells defeat.” @andreivkozyrev, the former Russian foreign minister, joins “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/Y7inFgURwZ
While much of the world seeks an urgent end to Ukraine’s agonies, China is biding its time and thinking ahead https://t.co/iN7wZ00HDo
Germany is preparing to pull its weight. The task now is to make sure that the effort is sustained https://t.co/vrLhJT6Fww
In 2020 malaria killed 627,000 people, of whom 96% lived in Africa https://t.co/sy35UUU1Gg
Should biological facts sometimes override people’s self-identified gender? https://t.co/FwsePWSAny
As families break up, with fathers staying to fight in Ukraine, many see no reason to compound the children’s distress by leaving pets behind https://t.co/QiD1EoTuKv

“As the price of fertiliser increases…so will the cost of coffee, sugar and soybeans, and every food that has these as ingredients.” @welshce, director of @CSISFood, explains how the war in Ukraine is affecting food supply globally, on “Money Talks” https://t.co/mIgqf3fr5Y
“My parents don't know where I am”: @Wendell23 reports on the foreign volunteers fighting in Ukraine. From @1843mag https://t.co/LhNjJ6sIaw
The chances of a conflict escalating into a nuclear war are greater than they have been for more than half a century. But that does not mean such a development is likely https://t.co/VYhtmjzzyK
China’s economy is ten times larger than Russia’s. China has thrived under today’s world order, whereas Russia has only undermined it. The West can exploit this https://t.co/8sXN2lb5Ra
One fear is that Russia might directly attack arms depots or shipments on the soil of a NATO member state as an indirect route to the use of nuclear arms https://t.co/Y2eaQBtEvG

I've written a detailed piece on Germany's "Zeitenwende". At least for now, it's less a foreign-policy revolution than a reluctant acknowledgement that the German dream of a European space governed by co-operation has given way to an era of confrontation. https://t.co/zZBN2yzOHA
Olaf Scholz has pulled the plug on Nord Stream 2 and aims to reduce Germany’s reliance on Russian energy. Few expected the typically cautious chancellor to react so decisively https://t.co/sW6TzAvapk

“If Ukraine becomes westernised…Russian people will look over the border and they will say, how come our brothers are free and prosperous?”@andreivkozyrev, Russia’s former foreign minister, ponders Vladimir Putin’s fears in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks”https://t.co/W0bud1Z3gP
Ukrainian troops are defiant, confident and buoyed by their success not just in holding out in many places for three weeks but in imposing serious losses on the enemy https://t.co/qxyyF3un1H
When Pasha Lee's body was found it emerged that he had taken off his bulletproof vest to give it to a child he was carrying. Read his obituary: https://t.co/kj07HgbNCS https://t.co/Cl45bftL2B
Biology must sometimes trump identity. Sport offers the clearest example of why https://t.co/VmszwqispV

Having defended democracy, Western countries need to reinforce it. Joined-up action on trade and defence would send a warning to China about what would happen were it to invade Taiwan https://t.co/cgNj2nOT8O
The high number of deaths so early on in the war is striking https://t.co/E7L7Kt9Sdz
The long-term economic effects of Vladimir Putin’s invasion will be felt far beyond Ukraine https://t.co/EnzwSfGm2k

“No matter how the war unfolds, China will treat its relationship with the Kremlin as a means of boosting Chinese power, not Russia’s”—several of my colleagues explain how China thinks it can benefit from the Ukraine conflict https://t.co/z01fcfSqzX
Germany’s attitude to defence has changed with dizzying speed. Germany will send arms to Ukraine and spend €100bn to equip its own military https://t.co/keWYah4pcu
Russian forces are firmly positioned on the outskirts of Kyiv. More and more missiles and rockets are hitting the capital. But that fire has been returned https://t.co/CB6PSvWPPR
Vitaly Kim’s now famous daily video blogs combine humour with withering putdowns of the “idiotic” Russian army. But when he speaks, people listen https://t.co/aY3Ml4R4s2

What Vladimir Putin has done, in addition to shattering unity, is “undermine and debase Russia’s most important source of economic power”, argues the award-winning author Daniel Yergin in a guest essay for The Economist https://t.co/whxKNKCYf5
Countries in Africa and the Middle East are likely to be the hardest hit by short supplies or higher prices https://t.co/0p3KJxBLRu
For companies that remain in Russia, the reputational cost of staying may soon become too high to ignore https://t.co/8TQ8HhcLFk
Western arms are still pouring into Ukraine. The only thing which may be more important to the country’s defence than these supplies is the morale they help keep up https://t.co/GdmmxqwWfT
In three weeks of Vladimir Putin’s war in Ukraine, four out of 20 or so Russian major-generals have been slain https://t.co/X5ooc6XTrn
The war in Ukraine will determine how China sees the world https://t.co/eGIAYxrRXM

“I have plenty of experience of dealing with bandits. After spending ten years in Russian prisons, I can say that the most dangerous thing is to show them any weakness or uncertainty,” warns Mikhail Khodorkovsky https://t.co/EsFBAGg6SW

NATO must defy Chinese predictions and remain united as the war in Ukraine grinds on. Diplomatic pleading will influence Chinese calculations less than Western resolve to make Vladimir Putin pay for his crimes https://t.co/uboYbVxOga
“My bosses don’t know where I am. I guess they’re going to find out in the Monday morning call”. Meet the volunteers fighting for Ukraine https://t.co/4vtsKnDYJa
Swimmer Lia Thomas is at the centre of a debate about whether trans women should compete in women’s sports https://t.co/PQeXs1AWx6
It would be remarkable if Chelsea were to find owners with pockets as deep as those of Roman Abramovich. It seems the club’s days of lavish spending are over https://t.co/fUlnyKDeHi
The invasion of Ukraine has undoubtedly moved the world past the threshold where nuclear war stops being unthinkable https://t.co/ppnxblpgNv
China sees Russia as a partner in dismantling the liberal world order. It thinks it can exploit the war in Ukraine to hasten Western decline https://t.co/yY9WewSaNH
Like the country’s president, Vitaly Kim is a political newcomer, an accidental war leader and a social-media darling https://t.co/pilbyDRjTd
Although consumers are feeling the pinch at the petrol pump, the average American car made in 2021 is 93% more fuel-efficient than one built in 1975 https://t.co/rIDzE2RR1l
Vitaly Kim’s composure has transformed him into a national symbol of resistance https://t.co/CRQsa9nSKy

“The consequences of the Ukraine war will turn Russia into a ‘reduced energy power’,” writes Daniel Yergin in a guest essay for The Economist. “This marks the end of an era” that began with the collapse of the Soviet Union https://t.co/onxSJ3TDVo
